title: Cascading effects of moose (Alces alces) management on birds
abstract: Large herbivores often have key functions in their ecosystems, and may affect ecosystem processes with cascading effects on other animals. The mechanisms often involve relocations of resources of various kinds, including reduction in resource availability following foraging and increase in resources from animal excreta. As large herbivore populations in Europe generally are intensely managed, management activities may interact with the activities of the herbivores themselves in the effect on other ecosystem components. We investigated the effects of moose (Alces alces) winter browsing, together with the effect of net nutrient input via supplementary winter feeding of moose on functional composition and species richness of birds in a boreal forest. Supplementary feeding stations for moose had a net zero effect on bird species richness and abundance, because negative effects of moose browsing were balanced by positive effects of nutrient input. Sites with a similar browsing intensity as at feeding stations but without nutrient input had lower abundance and species richness than feeding stations. Functional groups of bird species showed differing responses: birds nesting at or below browsing height were negatively affected by moose browsing, whereas species nesting above the browsing zone were positively affected by moose browsing. Insect-eating species responded negatively to moose browsing on birch but positively to nutrient input at feeding stations, whereas seed-eating species responded positively to birch browsing and negatively to feeding stations. This study showed that both high levels of cervid activity and human management interventions influence bird communities.

motivations: Large herbivores like moose have significant impacts on ecosystems, and their management can have cascading effects on other species, including birds.
Understanding the interactions between moose management and bird populations is crucial for effective conservation and ecosystem management.
objectives: Investigate the effects of moose winter browsing and supplementary winter feeding on bird species richness and functional composition in a boreal forest.
Examine how different bird functional groups respond to moose browsing and nutrient input from feeding stations.
methods: Conduct field research in a boreal forest to assess the impact of moose browsing and supplementary feeding on bird populations.
Compare bird species richness and abundance at sites with and without moose feeding stations.
Analyze the responses of different bird functional groups to moose browsing and nutrient input.
results: Moose browsing and supplementary feeding have contrasting effects on bird populations, with negative effects of browsing balanced by positive effects of nutrient input.
Different bird functional groups respond differently to moose browsing and nutrient input, highlighting the complexity of ecosystem interactions.
llama_json.research_subject: Cascading effects of moose management on bird populations in boreal forests

motivations: Large herbivores like moose have key roles in their ecosystems and their activities can have cascading effects on other animals.
The impact of moose management activities on other ecosystem components is not well understood.
objectives: Investigate the effects of moose winter browsing and supplementary winter feeding on the functional composition and species richness of birds in a boreal forest.
methods: Study the impact of moose browsing and nutrient input from supplementary feeding on bird species richness and abundance.
Analyze the responses of different functional groups of bird species to moose browsing and supplementary feeding.
results: Moose supplementary feeding stations had a net zero effect on bird species richness and abundance.
Bird species nesting at or below browsing height were negatively affected by moose browsing, while those nesting above the browsing zone were positively affected.

Insect-eating species responded negatively to moose browsing on birch but positively to nutrient input at feeding stations, whereas seed-eating species responded positively to birch browsing and negatively to feeding stations.
openai_json.research_subject: Effects of moose management on bird communities in a boreal forest

motivations: Large herbivores have key ecosystem functions that can create cascading effects on other animals, but these mechanisms are not fully understood.
Intensive management of large herbivore populations in Europe may interact with natural herbivore activities to affect ecosystem components in complex ways.
objectives: Investigate the effects of moose winter browsing and supplementary winter feeding on bird functional composition and species richness in boreal forests.
Examine how different functional groups of birds respond to moose browsing and nutrient input from feeding stations.
methods: Compare bird communities at moose feeding stations with sites having similar browsing intensity but no nutrient input.
Analyze responses of different bird functional groups based on nesting height and feeding habits.
results: Supplementary feeding stations showed net zero effect on bird richness and abundance due to balanced negative browsing effects and positive nutrient input effects.

Bird functional groups showed differential responses: ground-nesting birds were negatively affected by browsing while canopy-nesting birds benefited, and insect-eating versus seed-eating species showed opposite responses to browsing and feeding stations.
anthropic_json.research_subject: Cascading effects of moose management on boreal forest bird communities
